OXYBUTYNIN HYDROCHLORIDE

ANTIMUSCARINICS (SYSTEMIC)

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Renal impairment
  • Side effects

  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Urinary frequency, Urinary urgency, Urinary incontinence, Neurogenic bladder instability,

By transdermal application using patches

  • For adults
    Initially 5 mg 2–3 times a day, (by mouth) increased if necessary up to 5 mg 4 times a day.
  • For adults elderly
    Initially 2.5–3 mg twice daily, (by mouth using immediate-release medicines) increased if tolerated to 5 mg twice daily, adjusted according to response.
  • For adults
    Initially 5 mg once daily, (by mouth) increased in steps of 5 mg every 1 week, adjusted according to response; maximum 20 mg per day.
  • For adults
    Apply 1 patch twice weekly, patch is to be applied to clean, dry unbroken skin on abdomen, hip or buttock. Patch should be removed every 3-4 days and site replacement patch on a different area. The same area should be avoided for 7 days.
  • For children 5–11 years
    Initially 2.5–3 mg twice daily, (by mouth using immediate-release medicines) increased to 5 mg 2–3 times a day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    Initially 5 mg 2–3 times a day, (by mouth) increased if necessary up to 5 mg 4 times a day.
  • For children 5–17 years
    Initially 5 mg once daily, (by mouth) adjusted in steps of 5 mg every 1 week, adjusted according to response; maximum 15 mg per day.

Nocturnal enuresis associated with overactive bladder,

Initially by mouth using modified-release tablets

  • For children 5–17 years
    2.5–3 mg twice daily, increased to 5 mg 2–3 times a day, last dose to be taken before bedtime.
  • For children 5–17 years
    Initially 5 mg once daily, (by mouth) adjusted in steps of 5 mg every 1 week, adjusted according to response; maximum 15 mg per day.

Dose equivalence and conversion

Patients taking immediate-release oxybutynin may be transferred to the nearest equivalent daily dose of Lyrinel XL

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturers advise avoid unless essential—toxicity in animal studies.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Manufacturer advises caution.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Manufacturer advises caution.

Known side effects

General side effects

uncommon: Anorexia, facial flushing,

rare: Night terrors,

notKnown: Cognitive impairment in adults,

Specific side effects

rare: application site reactions with patches in adults,

Directions for administration

With transdermal use in adults

Apply patches to clean, dry, unbroken skin on abdomen, hip or buttock, remove after every 3–4 days and site replacement patch on a different area (avoid using same area for 7 days).

Advice for patients and carers

With transdermal use in adults

Patients or carers should be given advice on how to administer oxybutynin transdermal patches.

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Oxybutynin for daytime urinary symptoms

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/oxybutynin-for-daytime-urinary-symptoms

National funding/access decisions

Cautions regarding administration

  • Acute porphyrias

Unlicensed use

In children

Not licensed for use in children under 5 years.

Intravesical instillation not licensed for use in children.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

In adults

The need for continuing therapy for urinary incontinence should be reviewed every 4–6 weeks until symptoms stabilise, and then every 6–12 months.

In children

The need for therapy for urinary indications should be reviewed soon after it has been commenced and then at regular intervals; a response usually occurs within 6 months but may take longer.

In children

Intravesical instillation may be available from 'special-order' manufacturers or specialist importing companies.

Prepared medicinal forms of OXYBUTYNIN HYDROCHLORIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral suspension, oral solution, bladder irrigation,
Tablet
Modified-release tablet
Oral solution
Transdermal patch
